⏺ Update(docs/chapters/01-graph-theory-database-foundations/index.md) ⎿  Updated docs/chapters/01-graph-theory-database-foundations/index.md with 905 additions and 1 removal 30 31 --- 32 33 - TODO: Generate Chapter Content 33 + ## Introduction 34 + 35 + Healthcare data is inherently interconnected—patients receive care from providers, undergo procedures, receive prescriptions, and + accumulate complex medical histories over time. Traditional relational databases, with their rigid table structures and expensive JOIN + operations, struggle to efficiently model these intricate relationships. Graph databases offer a fundamentally different approach, treating + relationships as first-class entities and enabling natural representation of complex healthcare networks. This chapter introduces the + foundational concepts of graph theory and graph databases, establishing the theoretical and practical groundwork necessary for modeling + healthcare data effectively. 36 + 37 + ## What is Graph Theory? 38 + 39 + Graph theory is a branch of mathematics that studies structures made up of objects and the connections between them. In graph theory, + these objects are called nodes (also known as vertices), and the connections between them are called edges (also known as links or + relationships). While graph theory originated in the 18th century with Leonhard Euler's famous Seven Bridges of Königsberg problem, its + applications have expanded dramatically in the digital age, particularly in domains requiring complex relationship modeling. 40 + 41 + In the context of healthcare data management, graph theory provides the mathematical foundation for representing clinical entities and + their interconnections. Consider a simple example: a patient visiting a healthcare provider. This scenario involves at least two entities + (the patient and the provider) connected by a relationship (the encounter or visit). As healthcare scenarios become more complex—involving + multiple providers, medications, diagnoses, procedures, and care plans—the graph structure becomes an increasingly natural and powerful way + to model the domain. 42 + 43 + ### The Building Blocks: Nodes and Edges 44 + 45 + Nodes represent discrete entities or objects in your domain. In healthcare applications, nodes commonly represent: 46 + 47 + - Patients 48 + - Healthcare providers (physicians, nurses, specialists) 49 + - Medical facilities (hospitals, clinics, urgent care centers) 50 + - Diagnoses and conditions 51 + - Medications and prescriptions 52 + - Medical procedures 53 + - Laboratory tests and results 54 + - Insurance claims 55 + 56 + Each node typically has a type (or label) that categorizes what kind of entity it represents. For instance, you might have nodes with + labels like Patient, Provider, Medication, or Diagnosis. This labeling system enables efficient querying and helps organize the + semantic structure of your data model. 57 + 58 + Edges represent the relationships or connections between nodes. In healthcare graphs, edges capture critical information about how + entities interact: 59 + 60 + - A patient HAS_DIAGNOSIS relationship connecting a patient to a specific disease 61 + - A provider PRESCRIBED relationship linking a doctor to a medication order 62 + - A medication TREATS relationship indicating which conditions a drug addresses 63 + - A patient VISITED relationship documenting an encounter at a facility 64 + 65 + The power of graph databases emerges from treating these edges as first-class data structures rather than as implicit foreign key + references. Each edge connects exactly two nodes: a source (or start) node and a target (or end) node. 66 + 67 + 68 + Basic Graph Structure Diagram 69 + Type: diagram 70 + 71 + Purpose: Illustrate the fundamental components of a graph—nodes and edges—using a simple healthcare scenario 72 + 73 + Components to show: 74 + - 5 circular nodes representing healthcare entities 75 + - Node 1 (blue): Patient "Sarah Chen" 76 + - Node 2 (green): Provider "Dr. Martinez" 77 + - Node 3 (orange): Diagnosis "Type 2 Diabetes" 78 + - Node 4 (purple): Medication "Metformin" 79 + - Node 5 (yellow): Facility "City Hospital" 80 + 81 + Connections (directed arrows): 82 + - Arrow from Patient to Provider, labeled "VISITED_PROVIDER" 83 + - Arrow from Provider to Diagnosis, labeled "DIAGNOSED_WITH" 84 + - Arrow from Patient to Diagnosis, labeled "HAS_CONDITION" 85 + - Arrow from Provider to Medication, labeled "PRESCRIBED" 86 + - Arrow from Patient to Facility, labeled "ADMITTED_TO" 87 + 88 + Style: Network diagram with labeled nodes and directed edges 89 + 90 + Labels: 91 + - Each node shows its type (Patient, Provider, etc.) and name 92 + - Edge labels clearly visible along the arrows 93 + - Small legend in corner: "Circle = Node (Entity)", "Arrow = Edge (Relationship)" 94 + 95 + Color scheme: 96 + - Nodes: Color-coded by type as specified above 97 + - Edges: Dark gray with arrowheads indicating direction 98 + - Background: White 99 + 100 + Implementation: SVG or diagram tool (draw.io, Mermaid, or similar) 101 + 102 + 103 + ## Properties: Adding Information to Nodes and Edges 104 + 105 + While nodes and edges provide the structural skeleton of a graph, properties add the descriptive details that make the data useful for + real-world applications. Properties are key-value pairs attached to nodes or edges, similar to columns in relational database tables but + with far greater flexibility. 106 + 107 + ### Node Properties 108 + 109 + Node properties store attributes describing the entity represented by a node. The schema-flexible nature of graph databases means that + not every node of the same type needs to have identical properties, though in practice, nodes of the same label typically share a common set + of core properties. 110 + 111 + For a Patient node in a healthcare graph, typical properties might include: 112 + 113 + - patientId: Unique identifier (e.g., "P-458392") 114 + - firstName: "Sarah" 115 + - lastName: "Chen" 116 + - dateOfBirth: "1978-04-15" 117 + - gender: "Female" 118 + - bloodType: "A+" 119 + - primaryLanguage: "English" 120 + - insuranceProvider: "Blue Cross" 121 + - policyNumber: "BC-7829384" 122 + 123 + Similarly, a Medication node might have properties such as drugName, genericName, dosageForm, strengthMg, manufacturer, and + ndcCode (National Drug Code). 124 + 125 + ### Edge Properties 126 + 127 + Edge properties store information about the relationship itself, capturing contextual details about how and when entities are + connected. This capability distinguishes graph databases from simple network diagrams—the relationships carry data, not just structural + information. 128 + 129 + For a PRESCRIBED edge connecting a Provider node to a Medication node, useful properties might include: 130 + 131 + - prescriptionId: "RX-2024-893451" 132 + - prescriptionDate: "2024-02-15" 133 + - dosage: "500mg twice daily" 134 + - durationDays: 90 135 + - refillsAllowed: 3 136 + - pharmacyInstructions: "Take with food" 137 + - reasonForPrescription: "Type 2 Diabetes management" 138 + 139 + This edge-property capability enables sophisticated analysis. For instance, you could query for all patients taking a specific medication + at a particular dosage, identify prescribing patterns among providers, or track medication adherence over time—all by traversing edges and + examining their properties. 140 + 141 + Here's a comparison of how properties are distributed across nodes and edges: 142 + 143 + | Aspect | Node Properties | Edge Properties | 144 + |--------|----------------|-----------------| 145 + | What they describe | Attributes of entities | Attributes of relationships | 146 + | Healthcare examples | Patient demographics, diagnosis codes, medication names | Prescription dates, encounter durations, test results + | 147 + | Typical data types | Strings, numbers, dates, booleans, arrays | Strings, numbers, dates, durations, quantities | 148 + | Schema flexibility | Optional; nodes of same type can have different properties | Optional; edges of same type can have different + properties | 149 + | Query usage | Filter nodes by attributes | Filter relationships by context | 150 + 151 + ## Directed Graphs and Graph Direction 152 + 153 + Up to this point, we've been discussing directed graphs—graphs where each edge has a specific direction, flowing from a source node to + a target node. The directionality of edges is semantically meaningful in most real-world applications, including healthcare. 154 + 155 + Consider the difference between these two statements: 156 + 157 + 1. A patient HAS_DIAGNOSIS of Type 2 Diabetes 158 + 2. Type 2 Diabetes HAS_DIAGNOSIS of a patient 159 + 160 + Only the first statement makes semantic sense. The direction of the relationship matters. In graph databases, we explicitly model this + directionality by designating one node as the source (or start) and another as the target (or end) of each edge. 161 + 162 + Directionality enables precise relationship semantics: 163 + 164 + - Patient --VISITED--> Provider (the patient visited the provider, not vice versa) 165 + - Provider --WORKS_AT--> Hospital (the provider is employed by the hospital) 166 + - Medication --TREATS--> Condition (the drug treats the disease) 167 + - Procedure --REQUIRES--> Equipment (the procedure needs specific equipment) 168 + 169 + Some relationships might seem naturally bidirectional, such as family relationships or colleague relationships. However, even in these + cases, graph databases typically model relationships as directed, sometimes creating two edges (one in each direction) when true + bidirectionality is semantically required. 170 + 171 + ### Directed Acyclic Graphs (DAGs) 172 + 173 + A special category of directed graphs, called Directed Acyclic Graphs or DAGs, prohibits cycles—you cannot follow a path of edges + that eventually returns to the starting node. DAGs appear frequently in healthcare data modeling for hierarchical or temporal relationships + where cycles would be semantically invalid. 174 + 175 + Common healthcare applications of DAGs include: 176 + 177 + - Clinical workflow progression: A patient moves through stages of care (admission → triage → examination → diagnosis → treatment → + discharge) without cycling back to earlier stages within a single encounter 178 + - Medical terminology hierarchies: ICD-10 diagnosis codes form a hierarchical classification where child codes inherit from parent + categories 179 + - Care plan dependencies: Certain procedures must be completed before others can begin (lab work → results review → treatment decision + → procedure scheduling) 180 + - Organizational structures: Hospital departmental hierarchies flow from executive leadership down through departments without circular + reporting relationships 181 + 182 + 183 + Directed Acyclic Graph Example: Care Pathway 184 + Type: diagram 185 + 186 + Purpose: Demonstrate a DAG structure representing a clinical care pathway where stages progress without cycles 187 + 188 + Components to show: 189 + - 8 rectangular nodes arranged in a flow from left to right and top to bottom 190 + - Node 1: "Patient Admission" 191 + - Node 2: "Initial Assessment" 192 + - Node 3: "Diagnostic Testing" 193 + - Node 4: "Test Results Review" 194 + - Node 5: "Treatment Planning" 195 + - Node 6: "Treatment Administration" 196 + - Node 7: "Monitoring & Evaluation" 197 + - Node 8: "Discharge Planning" 198 + 199 + Connections (directed arrows showing workflow): 200 + - Admission → Initial Assessment 201 + - Initial Assessment → Diagnostic Testing 202 + - Diagnostic Testing → Test Results Review 203 + - Test Results Review → Treatment Planning 204 + - Treatment Planning → Treatment Administration 205 + - Treatment Administration → Monitoring & Evaluation 206 + - Monitoring & Evaluation → Discharge Planning 207 + - (Optional paths) Test Results Review → Additional Testing (dotted line back to node 3 only if new tests needed) 208 + - Note: No cycles that return to previous stages 209 + 210 + Style: Flowchart-style diagram with clear directional flow 211 + 212 + Labels: 213 + - Each node shows the care stage name 214 + - Arrows labeled with action or transition 215 + - Annotation: "DAG Property: No cycles—each stage progresses forward in time" 216 + 217 + Color scheme: 218 + - Nodes: Light blue gradient 219 + - Arrows: Dark blue 220 + - Optional/conditional paths: Dotted lines 221 + - Background: White 222 + 223 + Visual notes: 224 + - Add small clock icons to emphasize temporal progression 225 + - Highlight the acyclic nature with a note: "A patient does not cycle back to admission during a single encounter" 226 + 227 + Implementation: Flowchart diagram tool (Mermaid, draw.io, or Graphviz) 228 + 229 + 230 + ## The Labeled Property Graph Model 231 + 232 + The labeled property graph (LPG) model is the most widely adopted graph database paradigm, implemented by popular systems including + Neo4j, Amazon Neptune, and Azure Cosmos DB. The LPG model combines all the concepts we've discussed—nodes, edges, properties, and + labels—into a cohesive, flexible data model particularly well-suited for complex domains like healthcare. 233 + 234 + Key characteristics of the labeled property graph model include: 235 + 236 + - Nodes have labels: Each node can have one or more labels (e.g., a node might be labeled both Person and Patient) 237 + - Nodes have properties: Arbitrary key-value pairs describe node attributes 238 + - Edges have types: Each edge has exactly one relationship type (e.g., PRESCRIBED, DIAGNOSED_WITH) 239 + - Edges have properties: Relationships can carry contextual information 240 + - Edges are directed: Every edge connects a source node to a target node 241 + - Schema flexibility: No rigid schema is enforced; the graph can evolve organically as requirements change 242 + 243 + This flexibility is particularly valuable in healthcare, where data models must accommodate: 244 + 245 + - Evolving medical knowledge and terminology 246 + - Integration of data from disparate source systems with different schemas 247 + - Patient-specific variations in care paths and medical history 248 + - Regulatory requirements that change over time 249 + 250 + Let's examine a concrete example of a labeled property graph representing a patient's diabetes management: 251 + 252 + 253 + (Patient {patientId: "P-458392", name: "Sarah Chen", age: 46, bloodType: "A+"}) 254 + -[:HAS_CONDITION {diagnosisDate: "2023-03-15", severity: "moderate"}]-> 255 + (Diagnosis {icd10: "E11.9", name: "Type 2 Diabetes", category: "Endocrine"}) 256 + 257 + (Provider {providerId: "DR-1892", name: "Dr. Martinez", specialty: "Endocrinology"}) 258 + -[:PRESCRIBED {prescriptionDate: "2023-03-15", dosage: "500mg twice daily", duration: 90}]-> 259 + (Medication {ndcCode: "12345-678-90", genericName: "Metformin", brandName: "Glucophage"}) 260 + -[:TREATS]-> 261 + (Diagnosis {icd10: "E11.9", name: "Type 2 Diabetes"}) 262 + 263 + (Patient {patientId: "P-458392"}) 264 + -[:VISITED {encounterDate: "2023-03-15", encounterType: "office visit"}]-> 265 + (Provider {providerId: "DR-1892"}) 266 + 267 + 268 + This representation captures entities (patients, providers, diagnoses, medications), their attributes (patient demographics, medication + codes), relationships (prescriptions, diagnoses, visits), and relationship context (dates, dosages, encounter types) in a natural, + interconnected structure. 269 + 270 + 271 + Healthcare Labeled Property Graph Visualization 272 + Type: graph-model 273 + 274 + Purpose: Visualize a labeled property graph representing a patient's healthcare journey with multiple interconnected entities 275 + 276 + Node types: 277 + 1. Patient (light blue circles) 278 + - Properties: patientId, name, dateOfBirth, bloodType, gender 279 + - Example: {patientId: "P-458392", name: "Sarah Chen", dateOfBirth: "1978-04-15", bloodType: "A+", gender: "Female"} 280 + 281 + 2. Provider (green squares) 282 + - Properties: providerId, name, specialty, licenseNumber 283 + - Example: {providerId: "DR-1892", name: "Dr. Martinez", specialty: "Endocrinology"} 284 + 285 + 3. Diagnosis (red hexagons) 286 + - Properties: icd10Code, diagnosisName, category 287 + - Example: {icd10Code: "E11.9", diagnosisName: "Type 2 Diabetes", category: "Endocrine"} 288 + 289 + 4. Medication (orange rounded rectangles) 290 + - Properties: ndcCode, genericName, brandName, class 291 + - Example: {ndcCode: "12345-678-90", genericName: "Metformin", brandName: "Glucophage", class: "Biguanide"} 292 + 293 + 5. Facility (purple diamonds) 294 + - Properties: facilityId, facilityName, facilityType, address 295 + - Example: {facilityId: "F-2201", facilityName: "City Hospital", facilityType: "Hospital"} 296 + 297 + 6. Procedure (yellow rounded rectangles) 298 + - Properties: cptCode, procedureName, category 299 + - Example: {cptCode: "99213", procedureName: "Office Visit Level 3", category: "Evaluation"} 300 + 301 + Edge types: 302 + 1. HAS_CONDITION (solid red arrow) 303 + - Properties: diagnosisDate, severity, status 304 + - Connects: Patient → Diagnosis 305 + 306 + 2. PRESCRIBED (solid blue arrow) 307 + - Properties: prescriptionDate, dosage, durationDays, refillsAllowed 308 + - Connects: Provider → Medication 309 + 310 + 3. TAKES_MEDICATION (dashed blue arrow) 311 + - Properties: startDate, adherenceRate 312 + - Connects: Patient → Medication 313 + 314 + 4. TREATS (dotted green arrow) 315 + - Properties: efficacyRating 316 + - Connects: Medication → Diagnosis 317 + 318 + 5. VISITED (solid green arrow) 319 + - Properties: encounterDate, encounterType, duration 320 + - Connects: Patient → Provider OR Patient → Facility 321 + 322 + 6. WORKS_AT (solid purple arrow) 323 + - Properties: startDate, employmentType 324 + - Connects: Provider → Facility 325 + 326 + 7. UNDERWENT (solid orange arrow) 327 + - Properties: procedureDate, performedBy 328 + - Connects: Patient → Procedure 329 + 330 + Sample data structure: 331 + Central patient node (Sarah Chen) with connections to: 332 + - Provider node (Dr. Martinez) via VISITED edge 333 + - Diagnosis node (Type 2 Diabetes) via HAS_CONDITION edge 334 + - Medication node (Metformin) via TAKES_MEDICATION edge 335 + - Facility node (City Hospital) via VISITED edge 336 + - Procedure node (Office Visit) via UNDERWENT edge 337 + 338 + Additional connections: 339 + - Dr. Martinez PRESCRIBED Metformin 340 + - Dr. Martinez WORKS_AT City Hospital 341 + - Metformin TREATS Type 2 Diabetes 342 + 343 + Layout: Force-directed with patient node in center 344 + 345 + Interactive features: 346 + - Hover over node: Display properties in tooltip 347 + - Click node: Highlight all directly connected nodes and edges 348 + - Double-click node: Expand to show additional connections (e.g., show all medications for a patient) 349 + - Hover over edge: Display edge type and properties 350 + - Right-click node: Show context menu with "Show all relationships" option 351 + - Zoom: Mouse wheel (zoom in/out) 352 + - Pan: Click and drag canvas background 353 + - Filter controls: Toggle node types on/off (e.g., hide Facilities, show only Patients and Medications) 354 + 355 + Visual styling: 356 + - Node size: Proportional to number of connections (degree centrality) 357 + - Node border: Thicker border for nodes with >5 connections 358 + - Edge thickness: Uniform for clarity 359 + - Edge color: Matches edge type (as specified above) 360 + - Selected node: Yellow glow effect 361 + - Connected nodes when selected: Light gray highlight 362 + 363 + Legend (top-right corner): 364 + - Node shapes and colors with labels (Patient, Provider, Diagnosis, etc.) 365 + - Edge line styles (solid, dashed, dotted) with meanings 366 + - Edge colors and their relationship types 367 + - Interactive instructions: "Hover to inspect, Click to highlight, Double-click to expand" 368 + 369 + Implementation: vis-network JavaScript library 370 + Canvas size: 900x700px 371 + Physics: Enabled with spring stiffness for natural clustering 372 + 373 + 374 + ## Graph Traversal and Paths 375 + 376 + One of the defining advantages of graph databases is their ability to efficiently traverse the graph—following edges from node to node + to discover patterns, calculate dependencies, or answer complex relationship queries. Graph traversal refers to the process of visiting + nodes and edges in some systematic order, often to find specific information or compute aggregate results. 377 + 378 + A graph path is a sequence of nodes connected by edges. Relationships between entities + are represented implicitly through foreign keys—a column in one table that references the primary key of another table. To query related + data, relational systems perform JOIN operations that combine rows from multiple tables based on matching foreign key values. 667 + 668 + For simple relationships or small datasets, this approach works well. However, as relationships become more complex and queries span + multiple levels of indirection, performance degrades significantly. Each JOIN operation requires scanning index structures and matching + keys, and these costs compound multiplicatively as query complexity increases. 669 + 670 + Consider modeling a patient's complete care network in a relational database: you might have tables for Patients, Providers, Medications, + Diagnoses, Facilities, Procedures, Insurance Plans, and Claims. Answering the question "Show me the complete care network for this patient" + would require JOINing across all these tables, filtering for the relevant patient ID, and assembling the results—a computationally expensive + operation. 671 + 672 + ### The Graph Database Paradigm 673 + 674 + Graph databases take a fundamentally different approach: relationships are first-class citizens, stored as direct pointer references + between nodes. This architectural choice, called index-free adjacency, means that traversing from one node to a connected node is a + constant-time operation (O(1))—you simply follow the pointer. No index lookup, no scanning, no matching. 675 + 676 + This design paradigm shift yields dramatic performance improvements for relationship-intensive queries. The same "complete care network" + query in a graph database becomes a simple traversal operation: start at the patient node and follow all connected edges outward, regardless + of how many types of relationships are involved. 677 + 678 + Here's a comparison of key characteristics: 679 + 680 + | Characteristic | Relational Database | Graph Database | 681 + |----------------|---------------------|----------------| 682 + | Data model | Tables with rows and columns | Nodes and edges with properties | 683 + | Schema | Rigid schema enforced | Flexible, schema-optional | 684 + | Relationships | Foreign keys (implicit) | Edges with types (explicit) | 685 + | Relationship queries | JOIN operations | Direct traversal | 686 + | Best for | Transactional data, reporting | Highly connected data, relationship analysis | 687 + | Query complexity scaling | Degrades with relationship depth | Near-constant performance | 688 + | Typical use cases | Financial transactions, inventory management | Social networks, recommendation engines, dependency analysis | 689 + 690 + ### When to Use Each Approach 691 + 692 + Both relational and graph databases have appropriate use cases. The choice depends on the nature of your data and the queries you need to + perform: 693 + 694 + Use a relational database when: 695 + 696 + - Data is primarily tabular with few relationships 697 + - Relationships are simple and rarely exceed 2-3 levels deep 698 + - Schema is stable and unlikely to change 699 + - Primary operations are CRUD (Create, Read, Update, Delete) on individual records 700 + - Strong ACID guarantees are critical for financial or transactional data 701 + - SQL expertise and tooling are abundant in your organization 702 + 703 + Use a graph database when: 704 + 705 + - Data is highly interconnected with many relationship types 706 + - docs.title: Learning Graph Viewer
docs.text:
Run the Learning Graph Viewer

This viewer reads a learning graph data from ../../learning-graph/learning-graph.json:

  1. Search Functionality - Quick node lookup with autocomplete
  2. Taxonomy Legend Controls - Filter nodes by category/taxonomy

docs.title: Search
docs.text:
• Type-ahead search for node names
  • Displays matching results in a dropdown
  • Shows node group/category in results
  • Clicking a result focuses and highlights the node on the graph
  • Only searches visible nodes (respects taxonomy filters)

docs.title: Taxonomy Legend with Checkboxes
docs.text:
• Sidebar legend with all node categories
  • Toggle visibility of entire node groups
  • Color-coded categories matching the graph
  • "Check All" and "Uncheck All" buttons for bulk operations
  • Collapsible sidebar to maximize graph viewing area

docs.title: Graph Statistics
docs.text: Real-time statistics that update as you filter: - Nodes: Count of visible nodes - Edges: Count of visible edges (both endpoints must be visible) - Orphans: Nodes with no connections (this is an indication that the learning graph needs editing)

docs.title: Sample Graph Demo
docs.text:
The demo includes a Graph Theory learning graph with 10 taxonomy categories:

  • Foundation (Red) - Core concepts in red boxes that should be pinned to the left
  • Types (Orange) - Graph types
  • Representations (Gold) - Data structures
  • Algorithms (Green) - Basic algorithms
  • Paths (Blue) - Shortest path algorithms
  • Flow (Indigo) - Network flow algorithms
  • Advanced (Violet) - Advanced topics
  • Metrics (Gray) - Centrality measures
  • Spectral (Brown) - Spectral theory
  • ML & Networks (Teal) - Machine learning

docs.title: Usage Tips
docs.text:
1. Hide a category - Uncheck a category in the sidebar to hide all nodes in that group
  2. Search within visible nodes - Use search to quickly find specific concepts among visible nodes
  3. Focus on a topic - Uncheck all categories, then check only the ones you want to study
  4. Collapse sidebar - Click the menu button (☰) to hide the sidebar and expand the graph view
  5. Find orphans - Check the statistics to see if any nodes lack connections

docs.title: Implementation Notes
docs.text:
This viewer follows the standard vis.js architectural patterns:

  • Uses vis.DataSet for nodes and edges
  • Implements node hidden property for filtering
  • Combines separate search and legend features
  • Updates statistics dynamically based on visibility
  • Maintains consistent styling across features

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text:
• Course planning - Filter by topic area to design lesson sequences
  • Concept exploration - Search for specific concepts and see their dependencies
  • Gap analysis - Use orphan count to identify disconnected concepts
  • Progressive learning - Start with foundation concepts, gradually enable advanced topics
